Lack enough support: The claim does not provide any evidence or data to support the statement that there are "at least 6 million workers" being paid below the national minimum wage level.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the introduction of the national minimum wage will automatically improve the wages of 6 million workers. However, it does not consider potential challenges or limitations in implementing the policy.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for why workers are being paid below the national minimum wage level, such as economic factors or employer practices.
Falters at times: The claim may be seen as faltering at times because it does not provide a clear explanation of how the national minimum wage will directly improve the wages of 6 million workers.
Understate: The claim may potentially understate the number of workers being paid below the national minimum wage level if the actual number is higher than 6 million.
Contradict fact: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim contradicts any established facts.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim exaggerates the number of workers being paid below the national minimum wage level.
